title: Vision Mission Need
text:
Vision
Mission




Be a beacon of hope, proffer the goblet of truth and offer a sip from the golden chalice
Bring harsh fact and good law together
Throughout this document, we’ll use words that may break your trend of thought. For instance “Adaptation” has a pretty loose definition in street use. However in climate science circles and also the places where that science matters (like funders) Adaptation means gearing (society/individual/infrastructure) up to deal with the effects of CC.
Click the icon below for enlightenment on some terms in popular use.

title: Vision Mission Need
text:
Goal
The overarching goal is to improve the Lambeau community’s understanding of climate change impacts and vulnerabilities for effective adaptation through implementation of a Vulnerability and Capacity Assessment.



Need
Timeline




Ensuring fisherfolk, homeowners, businesses and homeowners are not left behind in the aftermath of the February 2024 oil spill off the Lambeau coast
Remedy environmental injustice as soon as possible and if not the day after

title: Vulnerability Assessment
text:
Vulnerability Analysis==VA





A tool for all seasons (climate humour) VA is a risk analysis process designed to engage with communities in contexts where disasters (and climate change) are significant drivers of poverty and suffering. VA’s are a tool for gauging resiliency of a community. VA’s use a plethora of devices to arrive at a result: Which we will discuss enroute to advocating for the community of Lambeau.
Some background. Environment Tobago had done a mini Vulnerability and Capacity Assessment (VCA) in the Lambeau/Petit Trou geography as part of the project titled “Action by Civil Society in Trinidad and Tobago to Build Resilience to Climate Change project (2015 - 2017), with support from Conservation International and BHP Billiton Trinidad and Tobago”.
More recently (Dec 2023) we participated in a 4 day workshop for 14 countries from the region to acquire skills as trainers of VCA trainers. Both sessions as well as others too numerous to mention were facilitated by the Caribbean Natural Resources Institute. From this writers perspective therefore, ET is capable of conducting the necessary works to gauge the impact of February’s disaster on the village of Lambeau.

Here is the overview of the LM4eJ programme. Please pardon the succinct nature of the following list but it is imperative the upcoming scenario is framed. Rest easy tho, details are provided within this site. We intend to

The list above points to preparing a strategy for the village of Lambeau to deal with for untoward events that can hamper its ability to adapt rapid climate change.

title: Vulnerability Assessment
text:
We want to build Tobago’s climate defense (adaptation strategy) via a ‘natural forts’ approach. Where each village or community should function as a resilient outpost; by virtue of having strong ecosystems and functional natural services.
In a word Tobago’s resiliency to the effects of climate change is improved if each community is aware of and tending to its natural weaknesses and strengths. In the jargon, Build Tobago’s capacity for Disaster and Risk Reduction (DDR) via sustainable Climate Change Adaptation (CCA) practice.
We’d need to identify a path to achieve those ‘forts’. Along the lines of; Identify problems >> Assess needs >> Secure environmental rights >> Train the community to >> Restore Reinforce and Rebuild natural and where possible >> Monetise.
The following diagram outlines the step of the proposed LM4eJ initiative at Lambeau and environs with Environment Tobago leading with the Vulnerbility Assessment.

title: Vulnerability Assessment
text:
Partipatory Vulnerability Assessments
VA toolkits are generally in agreement that the best way to elicit information and help from a community is via meaningful engagement. Enter the participatory vulnerability assessment or PVA.
There are things the VA team will want to touch on before putting boots to the ground. Such as determining:

General Process and Scope:

How much time is available for the assessment?
On which areas will ‘team’ want to focus the assessment?
Who will perform the assessment?
Does Environment Tobago have the technical capacity to perform it in-house?
If outsourcing the PVA what is the procedure that must be followed for hiring the contractor?
What questions do we want the assessment to answer?
Which specific decisions do you want the assessment to support?

title: Vulnerability Assessment
text:
Budget and Political Support:
The Board of Environment Tobago will need to determine:

What is the budget for the assessment?

Who will manage LM4eJ and oversee budget?

Will Environment Tobago have political support for project?

title: Vulnerability Assessment
text:
Technical == Scoping

Will a model be developed for the assessment?

Will the THA be able to operate the model for future scenario analysis?

What future scenario will the Lambeau community want to model?

Best case. A regional best example?

Worst case. Do nothing?

Middle of the road. Best Tobago example?


Some of the above considerations are self explanatory while some will require decisions at Board level. In the meantime let’s get familiar with the rudiments of a Participatory Vulnerability Assessment (PVA) keeping Lambeau in mind.

title: Participatory Vulnerability Assessment
text:
If you’re here it means you have already read this page on the logic for deploying an intervention in the community of Lambeau. We shall now look into PVA methodology in case the term is unfamiliar.
List of tools which may be deployed for carrying out the Lambeau PVA**
Of the eight shown, what’s the least we can employ to obtain enough material to substantiate a case for getting help to Lambeau? All of the list of add to the knowledge-base though the 3D model may prove costly, cumbersome and may not have use afterward. Let’s look at each one.

title: Participatory Vulnerability Assessment
text:
Spatial mapping
Use a wide format printout (or have a good hand drawn outline map made) that the target group can circulate around. (Requires a suitable table) Have the target group enter the geography as they know it.
For example people could ‘place’ the school’s location, the fish retail outlet, the Pascal village stream, the hotel ruin, the bridges, the Shore Things restaurant and curio shoppe. All together such information - even tho its of diffrent things, comprise a spatial mapping exercise.

3D modeling
Participatory three-dimensional modelling (P3DM) is another tool that uses local knowledge to assess vulnerability and identify possible adaptation strategies. It facilitates the engagement of a wide range of stakeholders, such as community members, government ministers, technical persons, civil society and academia, in the process of assessing vulnerabilities in the areas where they live and work.
The three-dimensional model can be used to depict the past, present and future and is therefore a good tool to show the impacts of climate change and to plan for adaptation and resilience building. As the model is produced to scale, the information collected can be digitised and placed into a geographic information system (GIS) and used by a variety of planners to support decision-making. P3DM however, takes time to complete (typically between two weeks and two months).


Photo journaling
Is effective for our purposes as it allows for anyone (with a camera) to submit content. Allows for non current imagery to be display - which can also substantiate the historical timeline.
A photo journal is easy for us to share and easy for the receivers to consume when they do get it. Can also be used in other exercises over time.


Video journaling
Participatory video (PV) is a tool that can be used by community stakeholders to make their own video to tell the story of their vulnerability and capacity to adapt to climate change. It gives the community a direct voice using a very powerful communication medium that brings their challenges and issues alive for a wider audience.
PV can be useful for supporting advocacy, building consensus and exchange of ideas and experiences between groups or communities, including facilitating dialogue between groups, communities and stakeholders from outside the community. It can also be used for participatory monitoring and evaluation.
PV is not traditional documentary film-making. Community stakeholders are fully involved in all stages of the production of the video. The persons involved in the PV often move from being the “object of study” to become the “subject” of the process.
This enhances the participants’ motivation and attitude to take action. They decide what the issues and questions are, who should be part of the process, who needs to hear the messages and how those messages should be crafted and possible solutions. This includes creating a storyboard, capturing video clips of interviews with stakeholders and scene shots and direct editing of the video clips. The final product may take the format of a documentary, a skit or a music video.


 Surveys
Surveys can provide insights into people’s level of awareness of climate change and its impacts, the types of strategies for addressing impacts, and the various resources available in a community or sector.
You can ask questions that provide quantitative information (numbers and facts), such as household size, sources and level of income, or how often a community is affected by a particular climate hazard.
You should also include questions that provide qualitative information (descriptions), such as perceptions and attitudes about an issue.
Surveys unlike semi-structured interviews and focus groups, typically use a rigid format where participants are asked the same questions in the same order. This fixed format ensures reliable and comparable information across the surveys.
Surveys can be administered in a variety of ways, for example face-to-face, online (Meet, Zoom etc), via telephone or via mail or email).






Tips for developing survey questions





Keep them simple. Avoid using technical terms or jargon that may be poorly understood by respondents.
Be concise. Avoid long questions with multiple elements. They can be confusing as respondents don’t know which part to answer.
Avoid leading questions that direct participants to a particular answer. Instead of giving their honest opinion, participants will choose what they think is a good answer for you.
Avoid loaded terms. Loaded terms, like corruption or fines, can result in a negative reaction regardless of the question asked.
Keep the survey short: The quality of the responses will decline if it takes too long to get to the end of the survey.
Pilot the survey on a small scale before finalising and launching the full survey. This enables you to check that your selected interviewers have the necessary skills and respondents find the questions clear are providing the type of information you need.



Here is the link to one survey we used in Lambeau during the 2017 VA
And here is the link to the forthcoming LM4eJ survey This link is not active at this point but it will take you to a Google Form soon …


Livelihood Analysis
Livelihood vulnerability analysis is a systematic, participatory approach for analysing the vulnerability of a community’s livelihoods to climate change. It aims to engage the community in identifying how climate change is affecting their livelihoods, the drivers of vulnerability and ways to build resilient and sustainable livelihoods.
The analysis focuses not just on how community members earn a living, such as fishing, farming or tourism but also focuses on the wider concept of livelihoods assets and wellbeing. It also examines the opportunities and assets available to the community, and the different policies and institutions shaping these opportunities.
Through understanding the livelihood activities and assets within a community, you can analyse how they will be affected by climate change and the factors that make them more or less vulnerable. You can identify ways that communities can respond using their available assets. Additionally, you can identify entry points for building adaptive capacity and resilience into the future.


Value Chain Analysis
“Identifying key stages in an enterprise. It shows for example the steps from sourcing raw material for the product (and/or service), to sale, to the final consumer. It is used to improve the bottom line of an enterprise by adding value to its product or service” (Arline, 2016).

title: About the Lambeau Movement For Environmental Justice
text:
Further
Why litigate against the Government of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago?
Government will need to front the expenses for the cleanup and the overall restoration of the Lambeau coastline and Petit Trou lagoon - if other entities aren’t committed in a timely manner.
As articulated in the National Oil Spill Contingency Plan. (Section 6/Subsection 6.5. RECORD KEEPING AND PREPARATION OF CLAIMS (Page 46) Trinidad and Tobago have to make a claim to the International Oil Pollution Compensation Fund in accordance with the 1992 Protocol of the Convention on the Establishment of an International Fund for Compensation for Oil Pollution Damage.
This means there may be money coming in at some point and Lambeau needs to be positioned to collect some of it - And the only way to justify their cause, their right, is to make a credible case/ a scientific argument.
The litigation strategy is intended to keep the issue alive And to place the affected community at the top of the list for compensation. Obviously Government will extract its expenditure (fronted) towards the 2024 cleanup but the restoration should be managed by Tobago/ i.e. the Lambeau community.
What is unsaid is, Environment Tobago in empowering the cause of the Lambeau community is living up to its role as an advocate for environmental justice. Remember, Lambeau did not cause the February oil spill. They are simply victims of an injustice.
How  does Environment Tobago benefit the organisation or it members in oil spill involvement, beyond ‘just’ simply cleaning coast and wiping oil of wildlife?
This NGO’s strategic plan provides guidance (or strongly suggests) that we need an item that can generate income for the operations of the group: Preferably in a niche that is not overly popular and therefore highly competitive.
The oil spill has occurred at time when Environment Tobago has to hand, capability to assess and guide the Lambeau community to a place less vulnerable to unplanned disaster. And to greater appreciation of the Risks they face from the rapid onset of changing climate, given their proximity to the open ocean.
In short, the opportunity provided by the oil spill is something ET is uniquely placed to capture. Which begins with implementing a Vulnerability Assessment.

title: Environmental Injustice at Lambeau
text:
Environmental justice



Is the fair treatment and meaningful involvement of all people, regardless of race, color, national origin or income, with respect to the development, implementation, and enforcement of environmental laws, regulations and policies.
People of a community who are deprived of the right to a clean and healthy environment, the right to clean and healthy air, the right to clean and healthy water, the right and clean and healthy soil, the right to environmental protection and the right to balanced biodiversity are being discriminated against. Are victims of environmental injustice.
While the above ‘new’ rights are not yet totally codified in international treaties they are very evident in customary international law that protects spaces from environmental degradation. Using the Lambeau Movement For Environmental Justice it is my sincere wish and to have Environment Tobago follow in the footsteps of those who’ve won, who have righted environmental injustice where it matters most.. the poor the down-trodden the unhappy masses….(violins, harps and maiden song)
The diagram beneath, predicated on the rant above, posits some factors on which injustice (in the context of ‘natural environment’) feeds.

Let’s expand on the terms used in the above diagram.

title: Environmental Injustice at Lambeau
text:
Law
The THA Act is subsumed under the laws of national legislation. As concerns the Feb 7th oil spill, the legal framework is: Health [issues] are the business of the Assembly and National Security [issues] are under direct ambit of central government.
We could argue that the spill poses a real threat to the Tobago public - providing measurable impact to; homeowner rights to enjoy clean air, fisherfolk rights to derive a livelihood from coastal resources and the public’s right to the Lambeau beach. There will be other groups that can be impacted so the exhaustive list should be generated by consultation with the community and stakeholders - wherever found.
This opens up the option of pressing litigation against the THA. It also mean proving any arguments we make.
We’d want to argue the event could have been forestalled had the coast guard been doing their work. As the Prime Minister the Hon. Keith Rowley is on record as admitting the TTCG is having vessel issues. We could also make a case that State is in dereliction of duty. For which we use satellite tracking data that ‘put’ the leaking barge off Trinidad but well within our waters prior to dropping in at Cove.
The core argument is that the disaster could have been prevented had State’s resources functioned when tested in early February. As it turned out Coast Guard, posh radar systems and even calls from ordinary fishermen proved useless to the cause of the citizenry.

title: Environmental Injustice at Lambeau
text:
Water
Hydrocarbon compromised seawater systems that is, Tobago coastal waters from Cove Point to Scarborough threatens the resilience of the SE coast. While we not be able to argue this aspect as anyone’s culpability (except the captain and the owner of the tow) we’d want to document the spill related damage to this zone to substantiate a ‘loss’ argument.
As shown in the diagram, compromised resiliency is exacerbated by pollution. Deforestation in context is loss of mangrove.

title: Environmental Injustice at Lambeau
text:
Weak Civil Sector
A weakened people are prime candidates for environmental injustice. Resiliency (of a people) is hard to gauge but if a population is silenced or unable to give voice, or is ignorant of issues that affect their well-being the end result is low capacity to grow or in some cases even survive.

title: Environmental Injustice at Lambeau
section: Climate Change as contributor to e-injustice
text:
Climate Change as contributor to e-injustice
The rapid shift in climate norms is causing land loss (due to sea level rise, storms and other ‘natural’ phenomena). It is also compromising human health as well as the ability of people to produce food (e.g. compromised agrisystems).
A related and interesting curve to monitor here is how weakened biodiversity in natural ecosystems can be pushed over the ‘edge’ by short term thinking (by the farming sector) as they seek to drive of insect pests by spraying (for example). This is a classic case of destroying a natural infrastructure to facilitate an artificial unsustainable one.

title: Environmental Injustice at Lambeau
section: Land use as contributor to e-injustice
text:
Land use as contributor to e-injustice
As the shortage of ‘good’ land escalates we are witnessing higher prices for plots/parcels. Which as with the other indicators, adds to environmental injustice. Instances of land related injustice may be perpetrated by land-grabbers, extortion minded landlords Or by tenants who are simply wrong but strong.
A reverse manifestation of land not well utilised is urban decay. Urban decay is what could happen to Tobago should its fledgling tourism sector fold under the burden of negative press reports regarding the oil spill.

title: Environmental Injustice at Lambeau
section: Industry as a contributor to e-injustice
text:
Industry as a contributor to e-injustice
Fishing, treating water, mining oil, gas, sand gravel etc are all industrial activities that can push out those who are weaker if these industries are not well regulated.
Having defined (sort of), some key factors that can contribute to environmental injustice we see a possible focus for the Lambeau Movement For Environmental Justice initiative. So let’s keep the above to mind and take our ambitions to Lambeau; to discuss applying a vulnerability assessment.

title: LM4EJ
LM4EJ
text:
Knowledge of Impact is limited
All we know now is oil originated from a towed vessel (identified later as the MV Gulfstream) journeying from a point west; reportedly Puerto la Cruz, Venezuela and bound for Guyana. Satellite imagery provided by NOAA shows hydrocarbon leakage from 10 miles off Trinidad’s north coast. On February 7th 2024, four days afer leaving Venezuela waters the craft ran aground on a shallow reef off Cove Point, Tobago.




Figure 1: Stressed seagrape at Lambeau


The aftermath of the grounding saw hydrocarbon pollution on a fifteen kilometer (15km) stretch of coast between Cove Point to the southeast and Lambeau to the northeast. The spillage continued for some time after grounding. Reports indicate the bulk of the spill post-grounding was carried to sea by current/wind and was tracked out to a distance of 180 kilometers further west. [Update: To Bonaire’s coast]
Over the period Feb 11th to time of writing, crews have been working with the oil and the vessel. Otherwise, except for some vouchers (100 x $1000TT) the only attention given to the village has been mandatory relocation of the fish market and an ‘offer’ to the Lambeau fishermen to take their boats to another unaffected bay.
The most recent news, other than the cleanup messaging delivered by the Tobago House of Assembly twice a week is that a donation of USD $250,000 is on its way to the country courtesy the CAF. This is a welcome start to the recovery but Environment Tobago would like to get involved ina meaningful way.

title: LM4EJ
text:
Is intervention still timely?
It is. Oil remains, killing the mangroves, it passed / is passing through the water column of the lagoon and will affect the near-shore (fish) nurseries. Is presently and possibly for the medium term prove deleterious to community assets (beach, fisheries, loss of human well-being etc). To reiterate, are all unknown states.
For restoration in any of these arenas to be successful more information has to gained. Environment Tobago thinks before leaving such works totally to the authorities and to the institutions charged with environmental and social responsibilities we’d do well to recall it is by someone’s failure to do a job that this situation is now with Tobago.
Moreover. The chances of other unplanned for events remain - as both Climate and geopolitical realities escalate toward unknown but definitely unpleasant territory. In short Trinidad and Tobago is located in a very risky part of the world and we who live here should look to scaling our capacities. As well as our rights.
So we should intervene. Incidentally Environment Tobago is already committed to bringing environmental rights awareness to this T&T via the EnviroRightsTT project (launching March 21st 2024). So while we acknowledge the unfortunate turn of events in the southwest, the Lambeau situation looks set to test of our ability both to assist and to grow in. The idea expanded from the following page shows one way.

title: Objectives Activities and Output
text:
Objectives
In a nutshell:

To integrate disaster risk reduction (DRR) and climate change adaptation (CCA) into the future versions of the National Oilspill and Contingency Plan as pertains to Tobago. NOTE TO SELF (and possibly Toco)
To stimulate its creation and to inform the contents of a new Tobago focussed document akin to the abandoned Comprehensive Economic Development Plan (CEDP) that will integrate DRR and CCA measures
To monitor and evaluate the impact of actions taken to enable CCA policies, reduce Risk that compromises Tobago’s ability to adapt and assist in the identification and nurturing of new initiatives that facilitate timely Adaptation.
To lend support (including advocacy and consultation) to THA strategies for DRR, Adaptation and within those
Advance the Environmental Justice framework by lobbying for the Government of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago to sign the Escazú Agreement.

title: Objectives Activities and Output
text:
Outputs

Compile, integrate and share Geographic Information Systems (GIS) at the practical level, design and use opinion surveys online and in-person within communities, edit photographs and video, do livelihood and value chain analyses and where necessary (and affordable use 3D modeling to reinforce geographic reality.
Manifest, make or otherwise carry out a Participatory Vulnerability Assessment (PVA) of the Lambeau community with the high hoped for outcome it can be used further as a model for further assessments across the region.
Use the PVA to improve the community’s understanding of climate change issues affecting Lambeau village and its wetland ecosystem.

title: Budget
text:
Budget period == 90 Days





Decide the budget. Do not spend unnecessarily but also do not be thrifty at the expense of safety, comfort and well-being of the facilitation team and community participants. Utilise funds in a balanced way; in tune with the Tobago context and its living standards.

Budget lines:

Transport; estimate how much travel is involved and then budget for it.
Equipment; (photographic, laptops, recorders, batteries, first-aid kit, or any other as required) and stationery (flipcharts, markers, index cards, notebooks, etc); Make a list of what will be required, acquire quotations and prepare estimates well before committing to the project.
Daily expenses of facilitation team members; estimate what will be necessary to support carrying out the work effectively.
Consider a provision for meals, tea/coffee and snacks, and related catering arrangements. Estimate days required, who will supply it and the required food items. Consider if there will be any community-wide events requiring substantial catering, such as at the PVA process on outset and/or completion. Discuss with the community how this is to be best arranged as well as their funding requirements if they want to cater/host.
Budget for sundry expenses related to the PVA. For example, paying for transport of community members to participate in the PVA; or paying somebody to relieve women of their household tasks so that they are free to engage in the PVA. Make allowances for sundries which cannot be anticipated.
Budget for services which cannot be done in-house such as GIS mapping, modeling, biodiversity mapping or radio announcements or legal services.
Budget for a proportion of staff wages to come out of this budget - as percentile of time allocated. Include the cost of reporting (financial and the technical VA output)

title: Sensitivity to Climate Change Impact
text:
a/>Sensitivity





The degree to which a system is affected, either adversely or beneficially, by climate variability or change. The effect may be direct (e.g. a change in crop yield in response to a change in the mean, range or variability of temperature) or indirect (e.g. damage to income and health due to oil or toxic waste pollution from vessels in the sealane around Tobago).
